title: Business before an idol-festival
vignette: Pagans celebrate a major feast in three days. May Jews sell them goods now, knowing the profits will be offered in thanks to the idol?

options.text: Refuse all dealings until the festival passes.
Trade anyway to preserve income and goodwill.

title: Repaying a debt before the feast
vignette: A Jew owes a pagan money that falls due just before the festival. Paying now will fund idol worship; delaying risks breach of contract.

options.text: Pay on time despite the risk.
Postpone payment until after the feast.

title: Bathhouse with a goddess statue
vignette: A public bath features Aphrodite’s image. Is bathing there acceptable hygiene or forbidden participation?

options.text: Bathe; incidental presence is not worship.
Avoid; any benefit in an idol’s shadow is prohibited.

title: Walking beneath an idol’s arch
vignette: A monumental statue spans the city gate; passers-by must walk under it. Does passing show honor to the idol?

options.text: Walk through; intent, not posture, defines worship.
Detour to avoid implied reverence.

title: Renting a house in Israel to pagans
vignette: A landlord can lease property inside Eretz-Yisrael to idolaters, who may install icons at home.

options.text: Lease; normal commerce outweighs concerns.
Refuse; prevent idolatry on the land.

title: Selling animals likely for sacrifice
vignette: A pagan customer wants healthy cattle days before his festival—presumably for offerings.

options.text: Sell; once the animal leaves your domain, his use is his concern.
Refuse; aiding idol worship is forbidden.

title: Nursing a pagan infant
vignette: A Jewish wet-nurse is asked to suckle an idolater’s baby. No pay is offered.

options.text: Decline free service; avoid fostering affection (*lo teḥanem*).
Agree from compassion for the child.

title: Treating an idolater medically
vignette: A pagan patient seeks free medical care. Refusal may breed hostility; assistance may violate *lo teḥanem*.

options.text: Treat only for a fee to avoid gratuitous favour.
Treat gratis; human life overrides the ban.

title: Saving a pagan in mortal danger
vignette: An idolater has fallen into a river. Must a Jew rescue him?

options.text: Rescue; the value of life is universal.
Do not endanger yourself for a pagan; obligation applies only to fellow Jews.

title: Wine touched by pagans
vignette: A barrel of kosher wine is handled by an idolater. May the Jew sell it for profit or must he destroy it?

options.text: Sell or derive benefit; only drinking is banned.
Destroy; any gain from idolatry-tainted wine is forbidden.

title: Food cooked by pagans
vignette: A gentile neighbour sends cooked fish. Accept as a friendly gesture or refuse as *bishul akum*?

options.text: Accept and eat; promote harmony.
Refuse; rabbinic fence against intermarriage.

title: Teaching Torah under imperial ban
vignette: Authorities outlaw public Torah study on pain of death. Continue classes or suspend?

options.text: Continue openly; divine command overrides risk.
Suspend to preserve life.

title: Bribing a jailer to free a relative
vignette: A woman is jailed for crimes against the state. Her brother can bribe the guard—illicitly—to release her.

options.text: Pay the bribe; family loyalty and mercy first.
Refuse; bribery undermines justice and public order.

title: Selling weapons to potential foes
vignette: Pagans ask to buy swords and chains. Commerce brings profit, but the arms may be used against Jews.

options.text: Refuse the sale; don’t endanger your community.
Sell; a merchant may trade any legal goods.

title: Returning an idolater’s lost property
vignette: You find a pagan neighbour’s lost purse. Torah exempts you from returning it, yet keeping it may fuel hostility.

options.text: Return it for the sake of peace.
Keep it; *lo teḥanem* forbids gratuitous favour.

title: Giving gifts to idolaters
vignette: An influential gentile official hints he’d appreciate a personal present. Torah bans gratuitous gifts; refusal risks loss of favour.

options.text: Give the gift to preserve goodwill.
Decline; no free gifts to idol-worshippers.

title: Hiring a pagan wet-nurse for a Jewish infant
vignette: Only a gentile woman is available to nurse a Jewish baby; she may feed it non-kosher milk or worse.

options.text: Hire her—child’s survival overrides dietary risk.
Refuse; find any alternative even if costly.

title: Taking internal medical treatment from an idolater
vignette: A pagan surgeon offers to operate on a life-threatening injury. Halakha warns he might kill the patient deliberately.

options.text: Accept treatment—chance of cure outweighs risk.
Decline; better to risk illness than trust a potential foe.
